RPN scientific calculators were quite popular in the ’70s and ’80s, particularly for models produced by Hewlett-Packard. If you’re interested in building your own RPN scientific calculator, GitHubber ZOOXO has a great open source design.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
This RPN scientific calculator, called SCOTT, is the successor to ZOOXO’s previous design ScArY. That earlier project was based on a commercial development board and only had a 7 segment display. For this new model, ZOOXO decided to build the circuit from scratch, which allows for the use of a more versatile SSD1306 OLED display.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The other major components are a @microchipmakes ATtiny85 microcontroller and a 16 key one-wire keypad. Of the five regular I/O pins on the ATtiny85, only three are being used: two for the display’s I2C connection, and one for the keypad.

RPN scientific calculators were quite popular in the ’70s and ’80s, particularly for models produced by Hewlett-Packard. If you’re interested in building your own RPN scientific calculator, GitHubber ZOOXO has a great open source design.

This RPN scientific calculator, called SCOTT, is the successor to ZOOXO’s previous design ScArY. That earlier project was based on a commercial development board and only had a 7 segment display. For this new model, ZOOXO decided to build the circuit from scratch, which allows for the use of a more versatile SSD1306 OLED display.

After being sick for a few days this week, I wasn't really in any mood to tinker except focusing on trying to recover and get better.
.
Just to help myself ease back into the grove of tinkering I decided to take out this 128x32 OLED display that I bought some time ago from Lazada (since they were selling these Chinese made ones like really cheap online).
.
Normally, with such a small display (electronics components), it can be hard to tell what useful applications it might have in the real world.
.
But when you think about it, they might actually come in handy in handheld devices where a display is required and space is a constraint in the product design.
.
Think of a product like a hand-held probe or a handheld measuring tool of some sort.
.
I am pretty sure we can come up with some rather interesting applications if we simply put on our tin-foil hats.
.
I might not have much in my possession, that's a fact. I wished I had more. But I don't.
.
So sometimes I have to get creative with what I already have.
.
Its sad because sometimes I have to ignore many if the ideas 💡 that I have in my head simply because I don't have the means to materialize the idea into something physical.
.
Anyway, I'm just ranting. Lol.

RPN scientific calculators were quite popular in the ’70s and ’80s, particularly for models produced by Hewlett-Packard. If you’re interested in building your own RPN scientific calculator, GitHubber ZOOXO has a great open source design.

This RPN scientific calculator, called SCOTT, is the successor to ZOOXO’s previous design ScArY. That earlier project was based on a commercial development board and only had a 7 segment display. For this new model, ZOOXO decided to build the circuit from scratch, which allows for the use of a more versatile SSD1306 OLED display.

Making a display module for my clock (the red one from a couple of posts below). As you can see, the 0.96” OLED screens are a bit different. It turns out not all such screens are the same. The newer one is on the right, with larger holes. Also, many newer displays don’t have a resistor that allows one to change the I2C slave address, so if you buy those and want to use two of them at the same time, pay attention to this fact.

The golden cylinder in the middle is an orientation sensor (a simple switch which opens or closes when turned upside down). This will allow me to detect whether the clock cap is opened or closed.

A generous amount of hot glue always looks a bit messy up close, but it’s great to keep these tiny wires in place and remove any tension.

Self-proclaimed "hobbyist hardware enthusiast" @andrey.ovcharov wanted a Bluetooth FIDO2 authenticator, so he did what any self-respecting hacker would do: grabbed an ESP32 dev board and created a prototype. As he continued to iterate on the design, he added an ATECC508A secure element, and eventually a FPC1020AP capacitive fingerprint scanner. However, this presented an unexpected issue when attempting to open source the project: the fingerprint scanner required an NDA — plus the form factor was not particularly portable or robust anyway. 

So Ovcharov reimagined the device as a credit card-sized PCB! Replacing the fingerprint scanner with a simple capacitive touch keyboard and MPR121 I2C touch sensor controller, removing the battery, and integrating a small OLED display and SSD1306 controller allowed the design to stay under 2mm and thus become completely wallet-able.

RPN scientific calculators were quite popular in the ’70s and ’80s, particularly for models produced by Hewlett-Packard. If you’re interested in building your own RPN scientific calculator, GitHubber ZOOXO has a great open source design.

This RPN scientific calculator, called SCOTT, is the successor to ZOOXO’s previous design ScArY. That earlier project was based on a commercial development board and only had a 7 segment display. For this new model, ZOOXO decided to build the circuit from scratch, which allows for the use of a more versatile SSD1306 OLED display.

Did a pseudo longterm test today.

Sadly the problem is only weakened,  but not gone.
Got still two freezes below the one hour mark and also some spikes managed to get through the current filter.

The graphs show raw, unfiltered data for different wind speeds.
I really need a better filtering algorithm and a way to reset the arduino exactly after the main loop freezes.

Because interrupts and therefore hopefully timers, too, still work, I thought about a timed interrupt, which would trigger every few seconds or so, if the timer would not be resetted every time the main loop executes once.
Therefore, if the main loop freezes, the reset also stops and the interrupt service routine will reset the wifi module or even the mcu.

For the Arduino Uno timer interrupts are well documented and there even exist a few libraries that change the registers for you, but for the Nano 33 Series I only found sparse information. I assume I will have to dig into the original docu of its processor if I really want to know, how timer interrupts work on this board.
